Award.AwardTitle: Travel Support for Workshop: Rocky Mountain Summit on Quantum Information

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division of Computing and Communication Foundations

Award.AbstractNarration:
The purpose of this award is to support student travel to the Rocky Mountain Summit on Quantum Information, which aims to bring together leading scientists in the broad field of quantum information science. The focus of the workshop is on quantum information theory, in particular quantum Shannon theory, as well as quantum information methods employed in high energy physics and condensed matter theory. This is an important emerging research area, with a growing strength in US. The topic of focus is most closely related to Information Theory. A major venue in Information Theory, IEEE Symposium on Information Theory (ISIT), also supported by NSF, and this workshop are collocated, providing a unique opportunity to the workshop attendees to benefit from the participation of Information Theory community at large.

The award will support travel for up to 15 students and postdoctoral scholars to this workshop, focusing on those needing the support most and giving the priority to underrepresented groups. The workshop is to be held at the University of Colorado Boulder, from June 25 to June 29, 2018. Workshop website, http://jila.colorado.edu/rmsqi, provides general information about the workshop.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Rocky Mountain Summit on Quantum Information was a workshop held from June 25 to 29, 2018 at JILA, University of Colorado Boulder, and co-organized by Felix Leditzky, Graeme Smith, and Mark M. Wilde. The purpose of the workshop was to bring together researchers working in quantum information theory. It was organized with a focus on collaboration and discussions among the participants, accompanied by a sparse schedule of a few talks per day.


The goal of this travel grant was to allow US-based students to attend the workshop, present their recent work on quantum information-theoretic topics, and collaborate with fellow researchers on new projects. A particular focus was put on encouraging students from underrepresented groups to participate in the workshop.


The travel grant consisted of a total of $10,000.00, and financial support was offered to 8 US-based students.   Among those 8 students, one was female.  In addition, 6 came from ethnic minority groups (1 female student from India, 3 male students from India, 1 male student from China, 1 male student from South Korea). The home institutions of the awarded institutions included Louisiana State University (5 students; note, Louisiana is an EPSCoR state), University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign (2 students), and Yale University (1 student). Three of the 8 students decided not to make use of the travel support, so not all $10,000 were spent. All funded participants presented their recent work in talks and participated in the collaborative discussions that formed the major part of the workshop.
